(4) Developer shall not be required to install permanent underground irrigation for normal required town landscaping and irrigation improvements. 
Now, therefore, for and in consideration of the sum of $1.00 and other good and valuable consideration, including the consideration the town is allowing ___________ to install irrigation and landscape improvements within the town's medians and rights-of-way which the town will eventually assume maintenance responsibilities, and including the mutual covenants and promises contained herein, the receipt and sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged, the parties hereto agree as follows: 
(1)  ___________ shall be permitted and shall have the responsibility to install, improve, operate and maintain all landscaping and irrigation facilities within the medians and rights-of-way for ___________ Roads, within the parameters of the property, subject to the town's approval of plans and specifications as provided herein (hereinafter called "landscaping and irrigation improvements"). 
(2)  Prior to installation of the landscaping and irrigation improvements, ___________ shall submit to the director, in duplicate, complete plans and specifications for the landscaping and irrigation improvements, which plans and specifications shall be prepared by a landscape architect or practicing professional in the field. 
Plans and specifications shall be drawn to scale, including dimensions and distances, and shall clearly indicate the location, type, size and description of all proposed landscape materials and irrigation facilities, including total quantities. In addition, the plans and specifications shall clearly indicate the configuration, location, type and total number of heads and controllers to be used in the irrigation system. 
(3)  Upon submission of the plans and specifications, the director shall review same and shall approve same to determine that the landscaping and irrigation improvements are of such quality as to improve and enhance the surrounding areas, and do not violate any town ordinance or other regulation. All landscaping and irrigation improvements shall be installed within the medians and rights-of-way in full compliance and in accordance with the plans and specifications as approved by the town. 
(4)  ___________ shall furnish or cause to be furnished, at its expense, all labor, equipment, accessories, water and electrical utilities and all other services necessary to install, operate and maintain the landscaping and irrigation improvements in accordance with the plans and specifications. The director, or his or her designee, shall have the right to inspect the installation of landscaping and irrigation improvements and shall require such steps by ___________ that in the director's, or his or her designee's, opinion are necessary to cause proper installation in accordance with the plans and specifications. Upon completion of installation mentioned above, the director shall provide ___________ with written confirmation when, in the director's opinion, the landscaping and irrigation improvements have been installed in compliance with the plans and specifications. It shall be the developer's responsibility to make all additions, corrections, renovations and changes to comply with the plans and specifications. 
(5)  ___________ shall not make any material change in the landscaping and irrigation improvements without first obtaining prior written approval from the town. Before approving any such changes, the town may require submission of new plans and specifications for approval in accordance with the terms and conditions of this agreement. 
(6)  The parties recognize that the medians and rights-of-way are public property, which have, or may have in the future, located within them improvements by public utilities, including the town. ___________ shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the town, its officers, agents and employees from and against all damages, claims, lawsuits, demands, suits, judgments and costs, including reasonable attorney fees and expenses arising out of such installation, operation and maintenance, including direct reimbursement of the town for the costs of any damage to town property. However, ___________ shall not be responsible for maintaining any public utilities located in the medians, rights-of-way or elsewhere. 
(7)  Except in the event of an emergency, the town will coordinate with ___________ to minimize damage to the landscaping the irrigation improvements should the landscaping and irrigation improvements be affected by any proposed town improvements to or maintenance or repair of ___________ roads or town utilities located therein. All damage to the landscaping and irrigation improvements caused by the town as a result of the aforementioned improvements, maintenance or repair by the town shall be repaired by the town. However, notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, at such time that the left-turn lanes on ___________ roads be installed, any damage caused to the landscaping and irrigation improvements within the medians shall not be the responsibility of the town, and such landscaping and irrigation improvements shall be repaired or replaced at ___________ expense. 
(8)  Should ___________ desire to erect, construct, and maintain other improvements in such medians and rights-of-way in addition to the landscaping and irrigation improvements, including such items as nondirectional signs, project identification, sculptures or other objects, ___________ must request and obtain prior written approval from the director which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Such additional improvements shall hereinafter be called "additional improvements." 
(9)  The parties recognize that one of the benefits that ___________ received as a result of this agreement, is the opportunity to install and maintain the landscaping and irrigation improvements which are above and beyond the normal improvements allowed in street medians and rights-of-way. The greater improvements shall enhance the value of the property. 
(10)  ___________ shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the town and its officers, agents, and employees, from and against all damages, claims, fees and expenses, arising out of, or resulting from, the installation, operation and maintenance of the landscaping and irrigation improvements, or additional improvements, provided for in this agreement. 
(11)  ___________, at its own expense, agrees to provide and keep in force during the term of this agreement, owner's excess liability insurance covering ___________ and the town as an insured party in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for bodily injury, including death; $300,000.00 for bodily injury, including death; $300,000.00 for damages arising out of or in connection with the installation, operation or maintenance of the landscaping and irrigation improvements as provided for in this agreement. All such insurance policies shall provide that the insurance policy shall not be cancelled by the insurer unless and until at least 30 days written notice of such cancellation is delivered by the town. ___________ shall furnish the town with certificates of insurance required by this paragraph. Such certificates must be delivered to the town before ___________ commences any work within the town medians and rights-of-way. 
(12)  Should any landscaping and irrigation improvements provided for pursuant to this agreement be damaged or destroyed by the fault of a third party, ___________ shall have the responsibility of pursuing recovery from such third party and shall hold harmless the town and its officers, agents and employees from or resulting from pursuing recovery from such third party. The obligations of and the benefits to ___________ under this agreement may not be assigned without prior written consent of the town. 
(13)  ___________ shall maintain the landscaping and irrigation improvements except that it may terminate some of its maintenance responsibility under the following conditions: 
a.  The developer's maintenance responsibility according to the approved landscape plan shall cease in a residential subdivision at the end of such time that 80 percent of the lots have building permits issued for the construction of homes, plus a period of one year. The developer's maintenance responsibility shall not be less than two years and not more than five years. 
b.  The developer's maintenance responsibility, according to the approved landscape plan, shall cease in a nonresidential development at the end of such time that 80 percent of the retail spaces have been issued certificates of occupancy, plus a period of one year. The developer's maintenance responsibility shall not be less than two years and not more than five years. 
c.  At the end of such time that the developer ceases maintenance responsibility in a residential subdivision or a nonresidential development, the town will not assume responsibility of the irrigation system until it has been inspected by the director or his or her duly appointed representative, and proven to be in proper working order. 
d.  Should the developer desire to continue maintenance at the end of his time of responsibility: 
1.  The town shall be responsible for the water used in the medians (grass and trees only). 
2.  The developer shall be responsible for the water used in all other portions of the medians and rights-of-way. 
3.  The town shall not be required to water its portion of the medians. 
4.  The town shall have the right to require at the developer's expense, that the developer change the irrigation system to allow the town to water its portions of the medians separately. In such an event, the town shall provide the meters. 
5.  At such a time the developer wishes to discontinue maintenance responsibility, the developer shall notify the director, in writing, three months prior to ceasing maintenance. 
(14)  This agreement embodies the entire agreement between the parties and cannot be varied, changed, altered or amended except by the written agreement of all parties hereto. 
(15)  All the terms and conditions of this agreement are hereby made binding on the executors, heirs, administrators, successors and assigns of all parties hereto. 
(16)  All notices permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been properly given or served by the deposit of such with the United States Postal Service, or any official successor thereto, designated as registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing adequate postage, at the address set forth below the signatures of the pertinent party. Each such notice shall be effective upon being deposited as aforementioned. The time period within which a response to any such notice must be given, however, shall commence to run from the date of receipt thereof by the addressee. Rejection of, the refusal to accept or the inability to deliver because of address change of which no notice was given, shall be deemed notified as of the date of receipt or rejection thereof. Any part shall have the right from time to time and at any time until the termination hereof, to change is respective address by notifying the other party, in writing, and each shall have the right to specify as its address any other address within the United States of America. 
(17)  This agreement shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Texas. Venue for any suit brought to enforce any rights or obligations under this agreement shall be Denton County, Texas. 
(18)  In case any one or more of the provisions contained in this agreement shall be held to be invalid, illegal or unenforceable in any respect, such invalidity, illegality or unenforceability shall not affect any other provision hereof, and this agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal or unenforceable provisions have never been contained herein. 
(19)  The effective date shall be the last date of any signature of a party as set forth below. 
In witness whereof, this agreement has been executed and delivered as of the effective date as herein provided. 
	Town of Flower Mound 
Date: _____ 	_____

(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 10.05(Exhibit C))  
Sec. 14-338. - Definitions. 
Lawn sprinkler system means irrigation system, sprinkler system, and/or any outlet on a sprinkler system or device with perforations through which water issues from a hose to sprinkle a lawn. 
Person means an individual, proprietorship, trust, partnership, corporation, association, customer, and/or user of the town's water system, or other legal entity, except for the town. 
(Ord. No. 24-10, § 2, 4-19-2010)  
Sec. 14-339. - Unlawful to operate sprinklers when temperature is at or below freezing. 
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or operating a lawn sprinkler system within the town to permit operation and engagement of such system when the temperature is at or below freezing (32°F or 0°C) or to permit water spray or water from the lawn sprinkler system to enter onto any streets, alleys, sidewalks, or thoroughfares of the town when the temperature is at or below freezing (32°F or 0°C). The official temperature at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport shall be used to determine and shall be prima facie evidence of the temperature at the time of the offense. 
(Ord. No. 24-10, § 2, 4-19-2010)  
Sec. 14-340. - Violation for penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. Each day any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such. Allegation and evidence of a culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under [this section]. 
(b)  In addition to the proceeding, under the authority of subsection (a) of this section, the town shall be entitled to disconnect or discontinue water services to any such person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 24-10, § 2, 4-19-2010)  
Secs. 14-341—14-370. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - MOBILE HOMES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Manufactured Housing Standards Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5221f. 
 
Sec. 14-371. - Unlawful to occupy except in conformance with zoning provisions. 
Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to occupy any house trailer or mobile home within the town, other than on an area zoned for a mobile home park or mobile home subdivision as provided in ch. 98, zoning, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.01)  
Sec. 14-372. - Exceptions. 
(a)  A house trailer or mobile home temporarily parked upon a lot or tract of land as a temporary construction office during the time of actual construction, and where no person occupies such house trailer as a dwelling or sleeping place. 
(b)  A house trailer or mobile home located upon a lot or lots and occupied and used as a dwelling by the owner of the lot under a special limited permit from the town council as provided in this article. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.02)  
Sec. 14-373. - Permit required. 
(a)  Any person desiring to locate a house trailer or mobile home upon a lot, other than in an approved mobile home park or mobile home subdivision, for use as a dwelling, shall file an application for special limited permit with the building inspector requesting that he be permitted to locate a house trailer or mobile home upon his lot for occupancy and use as a dwelling. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant; 
(2)  Legal description of the lot and the local address upon which the house trailer is to be located if a special permit is granted by the town council; 
(3)  Description and size of the house trailer proposed to be located upon the lot; 
(4)  A drawing or plot plan showing the dimensions of the lot and the location of the existing buildings or structures upon the lot, if any, together with the location of existing buildings and structures upon adjoining lots; 
(5)  The persons to occupy the house trailer or mobile home; 
(6)  The length of time for which the permit is desired, which in no event shall exceed one year. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.03)  
Sec. 14-374. - Permit fee. 
Accompanying any application shall be a mobile home permit fee as provided for in the fee schedule found in appendix A of this Code, payable to the town, to help pay the cost of processing the application and the cost of maintaining notices required by this article. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.04)  
Sec. 14-375. - Building inspector to inspect. 
Upon the filing of the application, the building inspector shall investigate the application by inspecting the house trailer proposed to be located upon the lot. He shall then advise the town council as to whether the house trailer meets the requirements of the building code and other applicable ordinances of the town, and whether or not the lot and house trailer, if allowed to be placed upon the lot, would meet all of the requirements of the building code, the zoning ordinance, and other applicable ordinances of the town. The building inspector shall forward the application, together with his report and investigation, to the town council. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.05)  
Sec. 14-376. - Public hearing requirements on all applications; notices. 
(a)  After receiving the application and report of the building inspector, the town council shall set a date for a public hearing on the application. Public notice of the public hearing shall be sent to owners of real property lying within 200 feet of the lot upon which the house trailer is proposed to be located. Such notice shall be given, not less than ten days before the date set for hearing, to all such owners who have rendered their property for town taxes as the ownership appears on the last approved town tax roll. Such notice may be served by depositing the notice, properly addressed and postage paid, in the town post office. 
(b)  After such public hearing, the town council shall either grant, grant as modified, or deny the request taking into consideration the location and size of the lot, the size and construction of the house trailer proposed to be located upon the lot, the population density in the area, the location and use of the buildings, structures, and land in the area; provided, however, that no request shall be granted if the house trailer or lot, or the lot with the house trailer located thereon, would be contrary to any ordinance or regulation of the town or in violation of any ordinance or regulation. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.06)  
Sec. 14-377. - Issuance of permits. 
After the public hearing if the request is granted, the town council, by resolution, shall cause a special limited permit to be issued authorizing the location of the house trailer upon the lot for occupancy and use as a dwelling along with any conditions which are necessary and desirable to carry out the purpose of this article and to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens, and the building inspector shall then issue a certificate of occupancy under the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.07)  
Sec. 14-378. - Permit does not waive other codes and regulations. 
Where applicable, all building codes, rules and regulations shall be effective as to house trailers and mobile homes located as allowed under a special limited permit. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.08)  
Sec. 14-379. - Use of mobile homes longer than one year. 
The maximum length of time a house trailer or mobile home may be located upon any tract of land under the same ownership or possession by the same person is one year unless an exception has been made by the town council due to extraordinary circumstances. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.09)  
Sec. 14-380. - Issuance of permit does not constitute rezoning of property. 
Issuance of such special limited permit shall in no manner constitute a rezoning of the area, and such permit may be revoked or suspended if the conditions shall be violated. Any time limit placed upon the special limited permit shall not entitle such use beyond its expiration. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 11.10)  
Secs. 14-381—14-410. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34. 
 
Sec. 14-411. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Person means an individual or a partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association or other legal entity however organized, or agent of such. 
Street or public street means any street, alley, avenue, lane, boulevard, drive, place or highway commonly used for the purpose of travel within the town. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.01) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-412. - Moving permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to move, remove from or relocate within the town any new or used house, building or structure or any assembled portion of any new or used, house, building or structure from a location within or without the town, without first obtaining a building permit. This section shall not apply to house trailers and mobile homes governed by article X of this chapter or to accessory structures as defined in the zoning chapter, nor shall apply to house trailers and mobile homes governed by section 14-421. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.02)  
Sec. 14-413. - Application, permit fee and contents. 
(a)  Any person desiring to move or relocate any new or used house, building or structure, or any assembled portion of any new or used, house, building or structure from a location within or without the town to another location, lot or tract of land within the town, shall file an application with the director of community development requesting permission to move or relocate a particular house, building or structure upon a lot or tract of land in the town. 
(b)  Upon the filing of the application, the applicant shall pay the town a fee to move or relocate any new or used house, building or structure as provided for in the fee schedule found in appendix A of this Code to pay the cost of processing the application. An application fee is not required when the structure is certified by the state. 
(c)  The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant, and proof that the applicant or his agent is licensed in compliance with section 14-421(6). 
(2)  Description and size of the house, building or structure to be moved, together with a picture. 
(3)  Legal description of the lot and the local address upon which the house, building or structure is to be moved or relocated. 
(4)  A drawing or plot plan showing the dimensions of the lot or tract of land upon which the house, building or structure is to be relocated, and the location of existing buildings or structures upon the lot, if any, together with the location of the existing buildings or structures upon adjoining lots. 
(5)  The number, make, type and weight of the vehicles, whether powered or otherwise, which the applicant proposes to use in the course of the move. 
(6)  A certificate of insurance showing insurance coverage in force by the applicant as follows: 
a.  Public liability insurance in amounts not less then $50,000.00 per person and $100,000.00 per accident for bodily injury, and $50,000.00 per accident for property damage. 
b.  Such insurance policies shall name the town as an additional insured covering all of the applicant's operations in the town. Written notice of cancellation of any policy shall be provided to the town manager at least 30 days prior to the date of cancellation. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.03)  
Sec. 14-414. - Inspection of building or structure proposed to be moved required. 
Upon filing of the application, the town's director of community development shall investigate the application by inspecting the house, building or structure to be moved or relocated, and the lot or tract of land upon which the house, building or structure is to be relocated. A determination shall be made as to whether the house, building or structure meets the requirements of the building code and other applicable ordinances of the town and whether or not the house, building or structure, if allowed to be moved to the designated lot or tract of land, would meet all of the requirements of the building code or other ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.04)  
Sec. 14-415. - Grounds to refuse permit. 
After a determination is made, no building permit will be issued if the following conditions apply: 
(1)  The house, building or structure to be moved could not, once relocated, meet all the requirements of all applicable ordinances of the town. 
(2)  The lot or tract of land after the house, building or structure is located thereon, would not meet all of the requirements of the applicable ordinances of the town. 
(3)  The house, building or structure to be moved has deteriorated more than 50 percent of its original value by virtue of fire, age or normal wear and tear of the elements. 
(4)  The relocation of such house, building or structure upon the lot or tract of land would cause injury to persons or property or damage to the street or other public improvements. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.05)  
Sec. 14-416. - Issuance of moving permit; conditions. 
The director of community development may authorize a building permit to be issued to move such house, building or structure upon the lot or tract of land, upon compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  The condition that an irrevocable letter of credit or performance bond, made out to the town, in a form approved by the town attorney and in the amount of the estimated cost of relocating the house, building or other structure and improving the same to conform to all town ordinances and state statutes, as approved by the town engineer, is completed and filed with the town secretary; 
(2)  The filing of the indemnity bond required by section 14-420; and 
(3)  Compliance with any other requirements or restrictions as the director of community development shall determine are necessary and appropriate. 
Such letter of credit or performance bond shall be available to the town to secure the proper location of the house, building or other structure in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.06)  
Sec. 14-417. - Time for completing exterior improvement. 
Once the house, building or structure has been relocated, the approved applicant shall have 90 days to complete all exterior improvements to such house, building or structure, including all masonry requirements and lot landscaping. The building official may grant one 90-day extension to this period. No additional extension can be granted by the building official, and any request of the applicant beyond 180 days must be submitted to the town council for approval. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.07)  
Sec. 14-418. - Certificate of occupancy not to be issued unless in compliance with town ordinances. 
The director of community development shall not issue a certificate of occupancy for use of such house, building or structure until it complies with all applicable ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.08)  
Sec. 14-419. - Governmental agencies are exempt from article regulations. 
The United States government, the state, the county, the town, independent school district or any other governmental agency of the federal, state, county or municipal government are hereby exempted from complying with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that each governmental agency desiring to move a house, building or other structure shall first notify the director of community development, in writing, of such proposed move, secure the approval of the director of community development of such proposed relocation of such building, and comply with the building code and other ordinances of the town. Additionally, all governmental agencies shall provide the required indemnity bond contained in section 14-420. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.09)  
Sec. 14-420. - Indemnity bond required. 
(a)  Any person shall, before moving any house, building, structure or assembled portion, along, upon or across any public street, avenue, thoroughfare, or alley in the town, file with the town secretary a surety bond executed by some good and solvent surety company, authorized to do business in the state, payable to the town for the use and benefit of any party injured as a result of the relocation of any house, building or structure, conditioned that the person applying for such permit will indemnify and save and protect the town and any injured person harmless from any and all damages arising from or caused by the moving of such house, building or structure. 
(b)  Such bond shall be for the sum of $1,000.00, and any person who is damaged, in any way, by reason of the moving of such house, building, structure or its assembled portion, shall be entitled to such bond pursuant to an order of any court having jurisdiction. Such bond shall be subject to the approval of the town attorney. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.10)  
Sec. 14-421. - Permit conditions. 
A permit to move any house, building, structure or assembled portion thereof, along, upon, or across any street, avenue, thoroughfare, or alley of the town, shall be issued by the director of community development, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant must have complied with the prescribed requirements for an indemnity bond and letter of credit or performance bond before a permit shall be issued. 
(2)  The route over which any house, building or other structure is to be moved is subject to the approval of the town engineer. 
(3)  No stakes, poles or other devices shall be driven into any paved portion of any street, avenue, thoroughfare, or alley, nor shall any device used in connection with the moving of any house, building or structure be attached in any way to electrical or telephone poles. The applicant shall guarantee, to the satisfaction of the director of community development, through letters of approval from all affected utility companies, that the payment of all expenses in the taking down, moving, disconnecting and connecting of any and all wire and poles in connection with any house or other structure shall be at the expense of the applicant. 
(4)  No permit shall be granted for moving any house, building or structure along or across any fire lane. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of the mover of any house, building or other structure to use due speed and dispatch in moving such house, building, structure or its assembled portion, and such mover shall in no case obstruct or otherwise interfere with traffic along or across any street, avenue, thoroughfare or alley for a longer period of time than is absolutely necessary under the circumstances, and such mover shall make a report to the chief of the fire department as to the location of such house, building, structure or its assembled portion, while the same is being moved over or upon any public street, avenue, thoroughfare or alley. Such mover shall keep such house, building, structure or its assembled portion properly lighted at night as a warning or danger signal to the public. 
(6)  The applicant or the person making the move for the applicant must be a licensed house mover by the state. 
(7)  The applicant shall perform house moving activities only during daylight hours. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.11)  
Sec. 14-422. - Mobile home permit required. 
Except, as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to move or cause to be moved any mobile home into or out of any mobile home park or mobile home subdivision as provided in the comprehensive zoning ordinance, as amended, without first securing a permit. Therefore, as hereafter provided: 
(1)  The owner and/or manager of a mobile home park or subdivision within the corporate limits of the town shall be responsible for notifying new and current tenants of the mobile home permit requirement. An owner and/or manager shall not permit a mobile home moving into or out of their park or subdivision without the appropriate town permit. 
(2)  The owner of a mobile home shall provide the following information to the town in order to obtain a mobile home moving permit: 
a.  Name and address of the owner of the mobile home being moved; 
b.  The make, model and/or serial number; 
c.  The year built; 
d.  The size or square footage of the mobile home; 
e.  Its present location and proposed new location by lot and block and subdivision or street number or other legal description of the property, the state and the county, and the city or town, if applicable; 
f.  Any other information deemed necessary. 
(3)  Accompanying any mobile home moving permit application shall be a permit fee as provided for in the fee schedule found in appendix A of this Code to help pay the cost of processing the application. 
(4)  A mobile home moving permit for the movement of a mobile home out of a mobile home park or subdivision shall not be issued until such time as the applicant has provided a correct forwarding address and has made payment of any and all outstanding tax liabilities. 
(Code 1989, ch. 3, § 12.12)  
Secs. 14-423—14-450. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - CONSTRUCTION WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, adopted March 2, 2015, amended Art. XII in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. XII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 67-05, § 2, adopted Aug. 15, 2005. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis. 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-451. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to: 
(1)  Assist in the management of facilities placed in, on or over the public rights-of-way in order to minimize the congestion, inconvenience, visual impact and other adverse effects, and the costs to the citizens resulting from the placement of facilities within the public rights-of-way; 
(2)  Govern the use and occupancy of the public rights-of-way; 
(3)  Assist the town in its efforts to protect the public health, safety and welfare; 
(4)  Conserve the limited physical capacity of the public rights-of-way held in public trust by the town; 
(5)  Preserve the physical integrity of the streets and highways; 
(6)  Control the orderly flow of vehicles and pedestrians; 
(7)  Keep track of the different entities using the rights-of-way to prevent interference between them; 
(8)  Assist in scheduling common trenching and street cuts; and 
(9)  Protect the safety, security, appearance, and condition of the public rights-of-way. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-452. - Authority and scope. 
No person shall commence or continue with the construction of facilities within the public rights-of-way except as provided by the ordinances and directives of the town. All construction activity in the public rights-of-way will be in accordance with this article. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-453. - Unauthorized use of public rights-of-way. 
(a)  The town may institute all appropriate legal action to prohibit any person from knowingly using the public rights-of-way unless the person has complied with the terms of this article. 
(b)  A person commits a class C misdemeanor offense who commences or continues with the construction of facilities within the public rights-of-way, except as permitted by this article or by state law. Each day the person continues with the construction of facilities or engages in maintenance that requires excavation in or blocks the public rights-of-way in violation of this article constitutes a separate offense. Any violation of this article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 per violation per day. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-454. - Conflict with franchise. 
To the extent the provisions of this article conflict with the specific provisions of a franchise granted by the town and accepted by the franchisee, the provisions of the franchise shall prevail during the term of the franchise. To the extent that the provisions can be reconciled, both the franchise and this article shall be given effect. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-455. - Definition of terms. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings ascribed to them below. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. 
Certificated telecommunications provider means the same as in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.002(2), as amended. Certificated telecommunications provider shall include any entity that has been granted a certificate from the Texas Public Utility Commission under V.T.C.A., Utilities Code ch. 54 authorizing that entity to provide local exchange telephone service. 
Construction means the construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, removal, excavation, maintenance, repair or other work in connection with facilities within the public rights-of-way. 
Contractor means a person registered with the town to construct facilities on behalf of a user within the public rights-of-way. This definition includes both contractors and subcontractors. 
Facilities means any and all of the wires, cables, fibers, duct spaces, manholes, poles, conduits, pipes, underground and overhead passageways and other equipment, structures, plant, and appurtenances and all associated physical equipment placed in, on or under the public rights-of-way. 
Franchise means the initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the town or other franchising authority having jurisdiction over the public rights-of-way, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, ordinance, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, or agreement. 
Permittee means a person who holds an issued permit from the town to work in the public rights-of-way. 
Person means an individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation, governmental entity or any other legal entity. 
Public rights-of-way means public right-of-way as that term is defined in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.002(6), as amended to include the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easement in which the town has an interest. The term includes Texas Department of Transportation right-of-way. 
Town means the Town of Flower Mound, Texas, or an authorized agent of the town. 
User means a person who owns and maintains facilities within the public rights-of-way. A user includes a franchise holder, certificated telecommunications provider, or property owner and their employees. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Secs. 14-456—14-470. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION AND PERMIT 
 
Sec. 14-471. - Registration. 
(a)  In order to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, all users and contractors within the public rights-of-way shall annually register with the town. This includes contractors working for the town on town projects. For entities with a current franchise, that franchise shall be submitted with the registration form. When any information provided with the registration changes, the user or contractor shall inform the town of the change before the change occurs. If the name of the company or responsible person changes, a new registration form must be submitted for approval. 
(b)  Said registration shall be upon forms supplied by the town and shall become null and void on December 31 of each year. An appropriate fee for registration shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of appendix A of the Code of Ordinances of the Town of Flower Mound. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  A registration fee shall not be charged to a residential property owner in connection with his legal residence. For this section, legal residence shall be defined as property for which a property owner shows proof of a homestead exemption. 
(2)  For entities with a franchise, no registration fee shall be charged and the registration shall be valid for the term of the franchise. 
(c)  The town shall issue a registration to the applicant if the town, after review of the application, determines that the applicant: 
(1)  Has complied with all requirements for issuance of the registration; and 
(2)  Has not made a false or inaccurate statement as to a material matter on the application for registration; and 
(3)  Has not failed to pay any fees owed the town as a result of work performed in the public rights-of-way. 
(d)  Any registration regulated by this article may be placed on hold or suspended by the town thereby preventing any additional permits being issued if it is determined by the town that corrective action is needed for compliance with the requirements of section 18-32. If any contractor registration is suspended, the procedures outlined in chapter 18, article II, shall apply. Any registration placed on hold more than three times in a calendar year may be suspended. 
(e)  The town shall revoke a registration if the town determines that the registration holder has: 
(1)  Given false or inaccurate information on the application for registration or in a hearing concerning the registration; or 
(2)  Violated the provisions of this article; or 
(3)  If the registration holder has a franchise with the town, violated the terms of the franchise. 
(f)  If the town denies or revokes a right-of-way registration, the town shall give notice by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the applicant or registration holder. The applicant or registration holder may appeal the decision to deny or revoke by filing written notice with the town manager, within five days after receipt of notice. The town manager shall mail or cause to be personally delivered, written notice of the time and place of a hearing on the appeal to the person appealing. The notice shall be mailed to the address specified in the notice of appeal form. The town manager shall conduct a hearing and shall make a decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. The decision of the town manager shall be final. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-472. - Construction permits. 
(a)  No person shall perform any construction of facilities in public rights-of-way without first obtaining a construction permit from the town. A completed application for a permit with all required information attached shall be submitted on forms supplied by the town. Permits will be limited to street sections, block sections, or addresses, at the discretion of the town. The submittal of a completed permit application with an attached approved permit from the Texas Department of Transportation shall serve as the construction permit for work within Texas Department of Transportation rights-of-way, once submitted, approved, and issued. An appropriate fee for permit application review shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of appendix A of the Code of Ordinances of the Town of Flower Mound. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Emergency responses related to existing facilities. When necessary to prevent service interruptions or the imminent threat of harm to persons or property, work may be undertaken without first obtaining a permit; however, immediately after cessation of the emergency a permit must be obtained for the work performed, or being performed, in the public rights-of-way and an updated map of any relocated facilities shall be submitted. Permits shall be issued only to persons who have a valid registration or franchise with the town. Permits shall be issued only to persons who will be doing the work within the public rights-of-way. 
(2)  Work issued as a part of a development permit, CIP project, or a building permit. 
(3)  Maintenance of equipment, such as exchange of equal parts, in the same location. 
(b)  Permit submittals will be reviewed and comments sent back to the applicant within ten working days. If the permit submitted is incomplete, the application will be rejected as an "incomplete submittal" and the determination shall specify the documents or other information needed to complete the application and shall state that the application shall expire if the required documents or other information are [not] submitted within 45 days after the date the application was submitted. Each subsequent re-submittal will be reviewed and comments sent to the applicant within ten working days. 
(c)  An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have expired 45 days after the date of submittal, unless such application has been pursued as provided above or a permit has been issued. The town is authorized to grant one or more extensions of time for additional periods not exceeding 45 days each. The extension shall be requested in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything else in this section, no work may begin until a permit has been issued and an onsite pre-construction inspection between the permittee and the town inspector has been scheduled and approved as required by section 14-484, "Notification of construction start". 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015; Ord. No. 42-19 , § 1, 9-3-2019)  
Secs. 14-473—14-480. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 14-481. - Compliance with permit. 
(a)  All construction in the public rights-of-way shall be in accordance with the permit for the facilities. The town shall be provided access to the work and to such further information as may be reasonably required to ensure compliance with the permit. 
(b)  A copy of the construction permit, and engineering plans if required, that have been reviewed and released for construction shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the town at all times when construction is occurring. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-482. - Time for completion. 
All construction authorized by a permit must be completed in the time specified in the permit. For good and satisfactory reasons, any permittee holding an unexpired permit may apply for an extension of the time within which work may commence under that permit when the permittee is unable to commence work within the time required by this article. The town may extend the time for action by the permittee for a period not exceeding 30 days on written request by the permittee showing that circumstances beyond the control of the permittee have prevented action from being taken. No permit shall be extended more than once. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-483. - Federal or state permits. 
A copy of any permit or approval issued by federal or state authorities for work in federal or state rights-of-way located in the town shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the town at all times when construction is occurring. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-484. - Notification of construction start. 
An on-site pre-construction inspection meeting must be scheduled and attended by the contractor, and construction must be approved by the town, before any construction may begin. Before this meeting is scheduled, all non-town owned utilities must be marked. During this inspection all town utilities will be identified and marked, if needed. In addition, during this on-site pre-construction inspection meeting the permittee shall provide the "One-Call" ticket number assigned in compliance with the Underground Facility Damage Prevention and Safety Act. The permittee shall also provide notification to property owners adjacent to the construction site by letter or door hangers at least 48 hours in advance of the start of construction. The notification shall include contact information. In the event the construction is an emergency response as described in section 14-472(a)(1), notification of construction shall be made to the town as soon as practicable, but no later than the next business day. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-485. - Compliance with codes and laws. 
Construction shall be in conformance with all town codes and applicable local, state, and federal laws. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-486. - Storm water and erosion control. 
The permittee shall be responsible for storm water management and erosion control that complies with town, state, and federal guidelines. Requirements shall include, but not be limited to, silt fencing around any excavation that will be left overnight, silt fencing in erosion areas until reasonable vegetation is established, barricade fencing around open holes, and backed silt fencing in high erosion areas. Upon request, the permittee may be required to furnish documentation submitted to or received from the federal or state government. Erosion control facilities shall be in place prior to commencement of construction. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-487. - Notification of damage. 
The permittee shall notify the town immediately of any damage to other utilities, whether owned by the town, another public entity, a franchisee or a private utility. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-488. - Working hours. 
Except in emergency situations, all construction within public rights-of-way shall be performed during standard daylight hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Saturday (collectively referred to as "standard working hours"). Notwithstanding the definition of standard working hours, all required inspections and the performance of any construction which requires monitoring by the town's inspection staff shall only be performed between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday ("regular inspection hours"), unless special hours have been approved. Construction not requiring inspections or monitoring by the town's inspection staff can be done at any time during standard working hours. Any construction performed under emergency conditions, or when construction must be concluded under artificial lighting, lighting shall be erected and directed so that it shall not shine upon any residence or create a visual traffic hazard. 
Required inspections and monitoring of construction by the town's inspection staff outside of regular inspection hours but within standard working hours may be requested by the permittee. The approval of any request to perform construction requiring inspections or monitoring of construction by the town's inspection staff outside of regular inspection hours but within standard working hours shall only be granted if: 
(1)  Contractor submits the request together with a detailed schedule of the construction proposed to be performed in writing to the town no later than 4:00 p.m. at least three days before the inspections/monitoring are requested to begin; 
(2)  Overtime sheet has been submitted, approved and required overtime has been paid; and 
(3)  Town inspection staff are available to perform the inspections and monitoring requested. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-489. - Worksite regulations. 
(a)  In performing the work covered by the construction permits, the permittee shall: 
(1)  Comply with trench safety requirements adopted by federal, state, and local law; 
(2)  Follow the appropriate national safety code, as applicable, regarding design and construction procedures; 
(3)  Compact the backfillings to a density of 95 percent standard proctor density, as determined by a testing laboratory so as to prevent settling when a trench lies under any town street, or within 18 inches of a town street, and otherwise, to a density which meets the North Central Texas Council of Government specifications, as adopted by the town; 
(4)  Install new facilities located within the right-of-way at a minimum depth of 24 inches, or at a minimum depth approved by the town, with the following minimum clearances, except where the town finds an alternate clearance can safely accommodate existing utilities: 
a.  All conduits that cross an existing sanitary sewer or water main shall have a two-foot minimum vertical clearance from any existing pipes; 
b.  All conduits that cross an existing storm sewer shall have a two-foot minimum vertical clearance from the exterior face of the existing storm sewer; and 
c.  All conduits that run parallel to an existing storm sewer, sanitary sewer or water main shall have a three-foot minimum horizontal clearance from the exterior face of the pipes or manholes and all electrical conduits shall run on the opposite side of the street from water lines; 
d.  All conduits crossing an existing traffic signal conduit shall have a two-foot clearance from any existing conduit; 
(5)  Have the obligation to use trenchless technology. The town may waive the requirement of trenchless technology if the town determines that the field conditions warrant the waiver, based upon information provided to the town by the permittee; 
(6)  Ensure that the portion of the public rights-of-way in which repair work is conducted is, at all times and to the extent practicable, kept free of accumulating water; 
(7)  Promptly remove from the public rights-of-way all earth, gravel, stone or other material excavated from the area of such repair work, which is not needed for fill material at that location; 
(8)  Notify the town immediately of any damage to other facilities, either town or privately owned; 
(9)  Ensure that newly installed facilities will not interfere with other facilities, in particular gravity dependent facilities; 
(10)  Maintain a vertical clearance of at least four feet below the bottom of the proposed stream bed or drainage facilities, if applicable. The applicant shall contact the town to determine whether future improvements to the channel may impact the cable alignment. 
(11)  Maintain a minimum of 20 feet vertical clearance above the top of pavement at any signalized intersection and shall not obstruct any traffic signal indication or detection device. No franchise device shall be attached to any traffic signal equipment. 
(b)  In performing work on facilities within the public rights-of-way, a permittee shall not: 
(1)  Unreasonably interfere with the operation of other facilities or equipment situated within the public rights-of-way, whether owned or maintained by the town or other users; 
(2)  Use dynamite or other explosives during the excavation without the prior written approval of the town; or 
(3)  Remove locate flags from a location while facilities are being constructed. 
(c)  A permittee is responsible for the workmanship and any damages by a contractor or subcontractor. This provision is not intended to affect any legal relationship between a permittee and its contractors. A responsible representative of the permittee will be available to the town at all times during construction. 
(d)  A permittee is responsible for: 
(1)  Physically verifying the location both horizontal and vertical of all affected facilities, or, if required by the town, hand digging or potholing, prior to any excavation or boring, with the exception of work involving only lane closures; and 
(2)  Obtaining line locaters from all affected utilities prior to any excavation. Use of the Geographic Information System or the plans of record does not satisfy this requirement. 
(e)  The town must approve in advance the placement of all franchise utility poles, manholes and/or handholes. Franchise utility poles, handholes or manholes shall not be located in sidewalks or handicap ramps, unless approved by the town. 
(f)  The town may stop work under the permit at any time upon finding that conditions at the worksite exist that pose an immediate risk of harm to persons and/or property. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-490. - Traffic, detours, barricades. 
(a)  Except in emergency conditions, a person shall obtain prior approval of the town when a street or sidewalk cut is required, and comply with all requirements of the town for street cuts. 
(b)  A permittee or person shall not cut or open more than one-half of the roadway at any time in order to maintain the flow of traffic at all times. However, in an emergency or with the permission of the town along with an approved traffic control plan, the total width of the roadway may be cut or opened provided barricades are placed at the first intersection each way from the cut and detour signs are erected. 
(c)  Except in an emergency, all street closures or detours that will exceed 24 hours in duration shall require an approved traffic control plan and shall be posted by a sign at least two days prior to the closure or detour. If a cut or opening in a street is left open after 4:00 p.m., a barricade or temporary fencing must be placed on both sides of the cut and flares or red or amber lights shall be placed in front of each barricade. In the alternative, the permittee may cover the cut with steel plates. 
(d)  In performing the work, a permittee shall furnish and install the barricades, flares, and lights as necessary, and in compliance with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices and an approved traffic control plan. In the event there is a conflict between the provisions of this article and the provisions of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, the latter shall be controlling. 
(e)  During the time the work is actually being conducted, the permittee shall provide a flagger to alert the public to the work, when required by the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices or when required by the town. 
(f)  Lane closures on arterial streets as shown on the town's thoroughfare plan will be limited to between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. All traffic control devices shall be in place prior to the start of construction. All lane closures shall comply with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. Traffic control plans shall be submitted and approved by the traffic engineer. Alterations to these lane closure times shall be approved by the traffic engineer or designee. 
(g)  Any work that may involve construction within the public rights-of-way adjoining a school within the town must be coordinated with the town so as to minimize traffic conflicts and street closures during school days. Lane closures near schools shall be limited to 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. while school is in session. Alterations to these lane closure times shall be approved by the traffic engineer or designee. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-491. - Information signs. 
For projects permitted in lengths greater than 1,000 lineal feet, a minimum three feet by three feet informational sign with four-inch letters stating the identity and the telephone number of the permittee shall be placed at the location where construction is to occur prior to the beginning of the work in the public rights-of-way and shall continue to be posted at the location during the entire time of construction. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-492. - Restoration of public rights-of-way. 
(a)  When a permittee completes construction the permittee shall promptly restore the public rights-of-way to a condition at least as good as existed immediately prior to work commencing. The permittee shall return all flowlines and grades in the public rights-of-way to their original condition and shall complete restoration, which shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Replacing or properly repairing the surface, base, irrigation system, and landscape treatment of any public rights-of-way that may be excavated or damaged by reason of the construction of the permittee's facilities; 
(2)  Replacing all ground cover with equal to the type of ground cover damaged during work, or better either by sodding or seeding, as directed by the town. 
(3)  Installing of all manholes and handholes, as required. 
(4)  Backfilling all bore pits, potholes, trenches or any other holes, unless other safety requirements are approved by the town. 
(5)  Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines. 
(6)  Restoring excavation site to town specifications. 
(7)  Removing all locate flags during the clean-up process. 
(b)  The permittee shall be responsible for any damage caused by its work in the public rights-of-way, whether to public or private property, and shall immediately repair or replace said property or compensate the owner for damage to said property. Until such repair, replacement or compensation has been made, the permittee's work shall not be deemed completed. Traffic signal damage must be repaired the same day by a qualified traffic signal contractor. The traffic signal must be placed back in full operation. 
(c)  The permittee shall complete restoration to the reasonable satisfaction of the town within 30 calendar days after completion of the work, unless otherwise extended by the town. 
(d)  Upon failure of a permittee to perform any such repair or replacement work, after five working days of receipt of a written notice given by the town to the permittee, the town may repair such portion of the public rights-of-way as may have been disturbed by the permittee. The permittee shall reimburse the town for the costs so incurred within 60 calendar days from the receipt of the town's invoice by the permittee. 
(e)  Should the town reasonably determine, within two years from the date of completion of the repair work by the permittee, that the surface, base, irrigation system, or landscape treatment requires additional restoration work to bring the work to a condition at least as good as existed immediately prior to the construction commencing, the permittee shall perform such additional restoration work. 
(f)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the town determines that the failure of the permittee to properly repair or restore the public rights-of-way constitutes a safety hazard to the public, the town may undertake emergency repairs and restoration efforts subject to the indemnification requirements of section 14-503. The permittee shall promptly reimburse the town for all costs incurred by the town within 60 calendar days from the receipt of the town's invoice. 
(g)  If a permittee performs emergency construction in the public rights-of-way pursuant to section 140-172(a) of this article, the permittee shall comply with the requirements of this section for restoration of the public rights-of-way. 
(h)  Although no work will be permitted on private property adjacent to public rights-of-way, these restoration provisions shall apply to any damages to the adjacent private property as a result of construction within the public rights-of-way. 
(i)  If the permittee fails to diligently perform the work described in the permit, abandons the job, or for other reasons does not complete the work within a timely manner, the town, after giving notice to the permittee, shall have the authority to take such action as is necessary to restore the public rights-of-way to a good and safe condition for the benefit and convenience of the public. If the failure to complete the work causes a safety hazard, the town shall commence restoration and shall notify the permittee as promptly as possible after commencing work. Under these circumstances, the permittee shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the town in restoring the public rights-of-way and shall make no claim against the town for any excess costs or expenses or damage incurred by the permittee on account of the town's action. 
(j)  If a permittee fails to perform necessary restoration in accordance with the requirements of this section, all work in progress, except that related to the required restoration, which has been permitted but not completed may be halted and the town may place a hold on any permits not approved until all restoration is complete. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-493. - Record drawings. 
When requested, the permittee shall provide "record drawings" within 90 days of completion of construction. The "record drawings" shall be in a format used by the permittee in its ordinary course of business, but may exclude customer specific, proprietary or confidential information. If the release of the location of any utility, including water and sewer or of the "record drawings" submitted under this section would jeopardize public safety, the information shall be considered confidential. In addition, if "record drawings" submitted under this section include information expressly designated by the user as a trade secret or other confidential information protected from disclosure by state law, the town may not disclose the information to the public without the consent of the user, unless otherwise compelled by an opinion of the attorney general pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, or by a court having jurisdiction of the matter pursuant to applicable law. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-494. - Emergency conditions. 
If the town manager declares an emergency with regard to the health and safety of the citizens and requests by written notice the removal or abatement of facilities, a permittee shall remove or abate the permittee's facilities by the deadline provided in the manager's request. Upon failure of a permittee to perform such removal or abatement after five working days of receipt of written request from the town manager, the town may perform such work. The permittee shall reimburse the town for all costs or liability incurred by the town within 60 calendar days from the date of the town invoice. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-495. - Conditions for occupancy of public rights-of-way. 
(a)  In the exercise of governmental functions, as lawfully authorized by state and federal law, the town has first priority over all other users of the public rights-of-way. The town reserves the right to construct sewer, gas, water, drainage and other pipe lines, cables and conduits, to do underground and overhead work and/or change aerial facilities, in, across, along, over or under a public street, alley, or public rights-of-way occupied by a user, and to change the curbs, sidewalks, or the grade of the streets in accordance with state and federal law. Other projects within the public rights-of-way, such as beautification facilities, will not have higher priority over other users. 
(b)  The town shall assign the location in or over the public rights-of-way among known users of the public rights-of-way with due consideration to the public health and safety considerations of each type of user and to the extent the town can demonstrate that there is limited space available for additional users, may limit new users, as allowed under state or federal law. 
(c)  If the town authorizes abutting landowners to occupy space under the surface of any public street, alley or public rights-of-way, the grant to an abutting landowner shall be subject to the rights of the authorized users of the public rights-of-way. If the town closes or abandons public rights-of-way that contains a portion of a user's facilities, the town shall close or abandon such public rights-of-way subject to the rights of the user. 
(d)  Subject to applicable state law, whenever the town has determined that removal, relocation, change, or alteration of a user's facilities in the public rights-of-way is reasonably necessary for the widening or straightening of a street, or because the facilities otherwise interfere with the public use of the public rights-of-way, upon written notice by the town, the user shall, at its own expense, temporarily or permanently, remove, relocate, change or alter the position of the user's facilities that are in the public rights-of-way within 120 days, except in circumstances that require additional time as reasonably determined by the town based upon information provided by the user. Prior to relocation, the town shall provide a suitable location within the public rights-of-way or another property or place for relocation of the facilities sufficient to maintain service. For projects expected to take longer than 120 days to remove, relocate, change, or alter, the town will confer with the user and will determine a reasonable period of time for the removal, relocation, change or alteration. Should the removal, relocation, change or alteration be deemed by the user to impose a significant financial hardship, the user shall have the right to present alternative proposals to the town and the town shall give due consideration to any such alternative proposals. This section shall not be construed to prevent a permittee's recovery of the cost of removal, relocation, change or alteration from private third parties who initiate the request for removal, relocation, change or alteration. If the permittee fails to relocate facilities in the time allowed by the town under this section, the town may pursue legal action to compel action by the permittee and to recover from the permittee any liabilities or damages incurred by the town on account of such delay. Notwithstanding anything in this subsection (d), the town and the permittee may agree in writing to different time frames than those provided above if circumstances reasonably warrant such change. Such circumstances may include, but are not limited to, weather conditions, emergency conditions, accuracy and completeness of engineering plans or changes in design, relocation, coordination and other criteria which may delay projects. 
(e)  A permittee may trim trees in or over the public rights-of-way for the safe and reliable operation, use and maintenance of its facilities. All tree trimming shall be performed in accordance with standards promulgated by the town including the prohibition of tree topping. A permittee trimming trees within public rights-of-way shall be either certified or shall have initiated the process to obtain certification using the standards of Tree Line USA, a program sponsored by the National Arbor Day Foundation. The permittee shall make reasonable efforts to contact affected property owners prior to necessary tree trimming operations. Should the permittee, its contractor or agent fail to remove tree trimmings within 24 hours under routine circumstances, or within 24 hours after all service restoration activities have been completed under emergency conditions, the town may remove the trimmings or have them removed, and upon receipt of a bill from the town, the permittee shall reimburse the town for all costs incurred within 60 calendar days. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Secs. 14-496—14-500. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INSURANCE 
 
Sec. 14-501. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  A permittee shall obtain and maintain insurance in the amounts reasonably prescribed by the town with an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas and acceptable to the town throughout the term of occupancy of public rights-of-way. At the time of registration, a permittee shall furnish the town with proof of insurance. The town reserves the right to review the insurance requirements and to reasonably adjust insurance and limits when the town determines that changes in statutory law, court decisions, or the claims history of the industry or the permittee require adjustment of the coverage. For purposes of this section, the town will accept certificates of self-insurance issued by the State of Texas or letters written by the permittee in those instances where the state does not issue such letters, which provide the same coverage as required herein. However, for the town to accept such letters the permittee must demonstrate by written information that it has adequate financial resources to be a self-insured entity as reasonably determined by the town, based on financial information requested by and furnished to the town. 
(b)  The permittee shall furnish to the town copies of certificates of insurance or proof of self-insurance evidencing the coverage required by section 14-502. 
(c)  Insurance policies shall: 
(1)  Name the town and its officers, employees, board members, and elected representatives as additional insureds for all applicable coverage. 
(2)  Provide for 30 days notice to the town for cancellation or non-renewal. 
(d)  The permittee shall immediately advise the town attorney of actual or potential litigation that may develop and affect an existing carrier's obligation to defend and indemnify. 
(e)  This section creates no right of recovery of an insurer against the town. The required insurance policies shall protect the permittee and the town. The insurance shall be primary coverage for losses covered by the policies. 
(f)  The policy "other insurance" shall not apply to the town if the town is an insured under the policy. 
(g)  The permittee shall pay premiums and assessments. A company which issues an insurance policy has no recourse against the town for payment of a premium or assessment. Insurance policies obtained by the permittee must provide that the issuing company waives all right of recovery by way of subrogation against the town in connection with damage covered by the policy. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-502. - Minimum amounts of insurance. 
(a)  Comprehensive general liability. 
Property damage ..... $1,000,000.00 
Personal injury ..... $1,000,000.00 
Products—Comp/OP AGG ..... $2,000,000.00 
Aggregate ..... $2,000,000.00 
(b)  Comprehensive automobile liability. 
Personal injury, each person ..... $500,000.00 
Property damage, each occurrence ..... $500,000.00 
(c)  Worker's compensation and employer's liability. 
Each accident ..... $1,000,000.00 
Disease—Policy limit ..... $1,000,000.00 
Disease—Each employee ..... $1,000,000.00 
(d)  Umbrella liability insurance. 
Combined single limit ..... $2,000,000.00 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
Sec. 14-503. - Indemnity. 
(a)  Except as to certificated telecommunications providers, each permittee placing facilities in the public rights-of-way shall agree to promptly defend, indemnify and hold the town harmless from and against any and all claims, demands, suits, causes of action, and judgments for: (1) damage to or loss of property of any person (including, but not limited to the user, a permittee, its agents, officers, employees, contractors and subcontractors; the town's agents, officers, and employees; and third parties); and/or (2) death, bodily injury, illness, disease, loss of services, or loss of income or wages to any person (including but not limited to the agents, officers, contractors, subcontractors, and employees of the user, a permittee, or the town, and third parties), arising out of, incident to, concerning or resulting from the negligent or willful act of omissions of the permittee, its agents, employees, contractors or subcontractors, in the performance of activities pursuant to this article. 
(b)  This indemnity provision shall not apply to any liability attributable to the negligence of the town, its officers, employees, agents, contractors, or subcontractors. 
(c)  The provisions of this indemnity are solely for the benefit of the town and are not intended to create or grant any rights, contractual or otherwise, to any other permittee or entity. 
( Ord. No. 12-15 , § 1, 3-2-2015)  
DIVISION 5. - NETWORK NODES AND NODE SUPPORT POLES 
 
Sec. 14-504. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this division is to establish policies and procedures for the placement of network nodes and node support poles in the public right-of-way and on service poles within the town's jurisdiction, which will provide public benefits and will be consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the town public rights-of-way and the town as a whole. 
(b)  Intent. In enacting this division, the town is establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by network nodes and node support poles, including without limitation, ensuring that network nodes and node support poles do not adversely affect: 
(1)  Use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places; 
(2)  Vehicular and pedestrian traffic; 
(3)  The operation of facilities lawfully located in public right-of-way or public property; 
(4)  The ability of the town to protect the environment, including the prevention of damage to trees; 
(5)  The character of residential and historic areas, and town parks, in which network nodes may be installed; and 
(6)  The rapid deployment of network nodes to provide the benefits of wireless services. 
( Ord. No. 28-17 , § 1, 8-21-2017)  
Sec. 14-505. - Adoption and implementation of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Title 9, Subtitle A, Ch. 284. 
(a)  The town hereby adopts and implements the authority promulgated by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Title 9, Subtitle A, Ch. 284, as it may be amended, subject to the limitations of the same. 
(b)  The definitions set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.002 are hereby adopted as if set forth herein in their entirety. 
( Ord. No. 28-17 , § 1, 8-21-2017)  
Sec. 14-506. - Small wireless facility design manual adopted. 
Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.108, the "Town of Flower Mound Small Wireless Facility Design Manual," as it may be amended from time to time, is hereby adopted as the design manual, which together with the regulations set forth in this article XII of chapter 14, where consistent with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 284, shall govern the installation, construction, maintenance and occupancy of the public right-of-way of network nodes and node support poles within the public right-of-way. 
( Ord. No. 28-17 , § 1, 8-21-2017) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 28-17 , adopted Aug. 21, 2017, incorporates to this article the Town of Flower Mound Small Wireless Facility Design Manual by reference.  
Sec. 14-507. - Conformance with the town's public rights-of-way ordinance. 
Installation of network nodes and node support poles within the public rights-of-way shall require a permit in accordance with section 14-472 of town Code of Ordinances. Any application for the installation of network nodes and node support poles within the public rights-of-way shall conform to this article XII of chapter 14, to the extent said article is not in conflict with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 284, and the Town of Flower Mound Small Wireless Facility Design Manual. All applications shall be required to include an appropriate fee in accordance with the provisions of appendix A of the Code of Ordinances of the Town of Flower Mound for a permit obtained pursuant to section 14-472 of the town Code of Ordinances.
