The town council shall appoint one or more court reporters to preserve a record in cases tried before the court of record in which the proceedings are not recorded by a good quality recording device. The court reporter must meet the qualifications provided by law for official court reporters. The court reporter may use written notes, transcribing equipment, video or audio recording equipment, or a combination of those methods to record the proceedings of the court. The court reporter shall keep the record for the 20-day period beginning the day after the last day of the proceeding, trial or denial of motion for new trial, or until any appeal is final, whichever occurs last. The court reporter shall not be required to record testimony or any proceeding in a case unless the municipal judge or one of the parties requests a record. The party requesting the services of the official court reporter shall bear the cost of those services. When an electronic recording device is being used to record the proceedings, it is not necessary to have a court reporter present to record the proceedings nor to certify the statement of facts. The town council shall set the compensation of the court reporter. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 5.02, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-103. - Transcript preparation fee. 
The town council hereby establishes a transcript preparation fee in the amount found in appendix A of this Code. This fee does not include the fee for an actual transcript of the proceedings. The party requesting an actual transcript must pay the transcript preparation fee and the fee for an actual transcript of the proceedings. The fee for a transcript shall include the actual cost, as invoiced by the court reporter, for transcribing the recorded proceedings and the cost for copies of the transcript at an amount per page as found in appendix A of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 5.03, 12-20-1999)  
Secs. 26-104—26-120. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Appeals 
 
Sec. 26-121. - Generally. 
A defendant has the right to appeal from a judgment or conviction in the court of record, as provided by V.T.C.A., Government Code § 30.00014, as amended. The state has the right to appeal from a judgment in the court of record in manner provided for by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 44.01, as amended. The appropriate county court of Denton County, Texas, shall have jurisdiction of appeals from the court of record. All appeals shall be conducted in the manner provided for by V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 30, as amended. Upon the enactment of this article, all cases for offenses alleged to have been committed on or after September 1, 1999, shall be appealed in accordance with V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 30, as amended. An offense committed before September 1, 1999, shall be appealed in accordance with the law in effect before such date. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.01, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-122. - Perfecting right to appeal. 
(a)  State law adopted. The town council specifically adopts state law, as amended, relative to appeals. 
(b)  Requirements. In order to perfect a right to appeal, the appellant must file a written motion for new trial with the clerk of court and must also give notice of the appeal to the appellee and to the court. 
(c)  Motion for new trial. The written motion for new trial must be filed with the clerk of court not later than the tenth day after the date on which judgment is rendered. The motion must set forth the points of error of which the appellant complains. The motion or amended motion may be amended with leave of court at any time before action on the motion is taken, but may not be amended later than the 20th day after the date on which the original or amended motion is filed. The court may for good cause extend the time for filing or amending, but the extension may not exceed 90 days from the original filing deadline. If the court does not act on the motion before the expiration of the 30 days allowed for determination of the motion, the original or amended motion is overruled by operation of law. 
(d)  Notice of appeal. If the appellant requests a hearing on the motion for new trial, the appellant may give the notice of appeal orally in open court after the motion is overruled. If there is no hearing, the appellant must file the notice with the court not later than the tenth day after the date on which the motion is overruled. The court may for good cause extend the time period for providing notice; however, the extension shall not exceed 90 days from the original filing deadline. If the defendant is in custody, the appeal is perfected when the notice of appeal is given as provided by Vernon's Ann C.C.P. art. 44.13, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.02, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-123. - Appeal bond. 
If the defendant is not in custody, the defendant may not take an appeal until the defendant files an appeal bond with the court of record. The bond must be approved by the court and must be filed not later than the tenth day after the date on which the motion for new trial is overruled. The appeal bond must be in the amount of $100.00 or double the amount of the fines and costs adjudged against the defendant, whichever is greater. The bond must state that the defendant was convicted in the case and has appealed and must be conditioned on the defendant's immediate and daily personal appearance in the court to which the appeal is taken. If the defendant is in custody, the defendant shall be committed to jail unless the defendant posts the appeal bond. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.03, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-124. - Record. 
(a)  Conformance to state rules. The record on appeal must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of a record on appeal in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended. 
(b)  Transfer. Not later than the 60th day after the date on which the notice of appeal is given or filed, the parties must file with the clerk of court the statement of facts; a written description of material to be included in the transcript in addition to the required material; and any material to be included in the transcript that is not in the custody of the clerk of court. Upon completion of the record, the municipal judge shall approve the record in the manner provided for record completion, approval and notification in the court of appeals. After the municipal judge approves the record, the clerk of court shall promptly send the record to the appellate court clerk for filing. V.T.C.A., Government Code § 30.00020, as amended, charges the appellate court clerk with the responsibility of notifying the defendant and the prosecuting attorney that the record has been filed. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, §§ 6.04, 6.05, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-125. - Statement of facts. 
The statement of facts must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of a statement of facts in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended. The appellant shall pay for the statement of facts. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.06, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-126. - Transcript. 
The transcript must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of a transcript in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.07, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-127. - Bills of exception. 
Bills of exception must substantially conform to the provisions relating to the preparation of bills of exception in the Texas Rules of Appellate Procedure and the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.08, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-128. - Brief. 
(a)  Generally. Both the appellant and the appellee are required to file briefs with the appellate court clerk. Each party, on the filing of the party's brief with the appellate court clerk, shall deliver a copy of the brief to the opposing party and to the municipal judge. The record and the brief, on appeal, shall be limited as far as possible to the questions relied on for reversal. The municipal judge shall decide from the briefs of the parties whether the appellant should be permitted to withdraw the notice of appeal and be granted a new trial by the court of record. The court of record may grant a new trial at any time before the record is filed with the appellate court. 
(b)  Appellant's. The appellant must file a brief with the appellate court clerk not later than the 15th day after the date on which the transcript and statement of facts are filed with that clerk. The appellant or the appellant's attorney must certify that the brief has been properly mailed to the appellee. 
(c)  Appellee's. The appellee must file its brief with the appellate clerk not later than the 15th day on which the appellant's brief is filed. 
(Ord. No. 79-99, § 6.09, 12-20-1999)  
Secs. 26-129—26-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - FUNDS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Secs. 26-151—26-170. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Municipal Court Technology Fund[5] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference— Municipal court technology fund, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.0172. 
 
Sec. 26-171. - Created. 
There is hereby created a municipal court technology fund in accordance with Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.0172. This fund shall be administered by, or under the direction of, the town council. 
(Ord. No. 71-99, § 2(1), 11-15-1999; Ord. No. 31-15 , § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 26-172. - Fee established. 
(a)  All defendants convicted in municipal court for a misdemeanor offense committed shall be required to pay a technology fee as found in appendix A of this Code as a cost of court. 
(b)  A person is considered convicted for purposes of this subdivision if a sentence is imposed on the person, the person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision, or the court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(c)  The municipal court clerk shall collect the costs and pay the funds to the municipal treasurer, or to any other official who discharges the duties commonly delegated to the municipal treasurer, for deposit in the municipal court technology fund. 
(Ord. No. 71-99, § 2(2), 11-15-1999; Ord. No. 31-15 , § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 26-173. - Purpose. 
The municipal court technology fund may be used only to finance the purchase of the following technological enhancements for the municipal court of the town: 
(1)  Computer systems; 
(2)  Computer networks; 
(3)  Computer hardware; 
(4)  Computer software; 
(5)  Imaging systems; 
(6)  Electronic kiosks; 
(7)  Electronic ticket writers; 
(8)  Docket management systems; and 
(9)  Any other item or service permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 71-99, § 2(3), 11-15-1999; Ord. No. 31-15 , § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 26-174. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 31-15 , § 2, adopted June 1, 2015, repealed § 26-174, which pertained to expiration and derived from Ord. No. 71-99, § 2(4), adopted Nov. 15, 1999.

Chapter 30 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 30-1—30-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm site means a premises served by an alarm system or CATV alarm system. 
Alarm system means a device or system which transmits a signal which summons an emergency service of the town. For the purposes of this section, the categories of alarm systems are robbery, burglary and emergency assistance. The term "alarm system" does not mean an alarm installed on a vehicle, unless used for a habitation at a permanent site, or an alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants within the premises, but does include a local alarm as defined in this section. 
Alarm system company means any person or company that sells, installs, services, monitors or responds to burglar alarm signal devices, burglar alarms, television cameras, still cameras or any other electronic device used: 
(1)  To prevent or detect burglary, theft, shoplifting, pilferage or other losses of that type; 
(2)  To detect or prevent intrusion; or 
(3)  Primarily to detect and summon aid for other emergencies, and includes persons relaying alarm notifications. 
Appeal hearing official means the town manager or his designee. 
Burglar alarm notification means a notification that summons the police, which was initiated or triggered by an alarm system designed to respond to a stimulus characteristic of unauthorized intrusion. 
CATV alarm system means a device or system that transmits or relays a signal by community antenna television cable, or indirectly, intended to summon emergency police services of the town. 
Commercial unit means any business establishment. 
Director means the chief of police of the town or his authorized representative. 
False burglar alarm notification means an alarm dispatch request to a law enforcement agency when a response is made by the law enforcement agency within 30 minutes of the alarm dispatch request and the responding law enforcement officer finds from an inspection of the interior and/or exterior of the alarm site no evidence of a criminal offense or attempted criminal offense. 
False robbery alarm notification means a robbery alarm notification to the police when the responding police officer reasonably finds there is no evidence of a robbery or an attempted robbery. 
Financial institution means an institution required to have an alarm system by the provisions of the Bank Protection Act of 1968 (12 USC 1882, as amended). 
Governmental unit means any agency of the federal or state government or a political subdivision of the state. 
Local alarm means any alarm system, other than an alarm system monitored by an alarm system company, that results in notification to and response by members of the police department due to activation of audible and/or visual signaling devices. 
Panel alarm means an alarm that is directly monitored by the public safety communications section of the police department. 
Permit holder means the person who has received an alarm permit and is directly responsible for management and control of the alarm site. In any multiple-family dwelling unit (more than four dwelling units per building), the permit holder shall be the owner of the premises or his representative. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.01; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998; Ord. No. 62-10, § 2, 10-4-2010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-32. - Responsibilities of alarm system companies. 
(a)  A person who is engaged in the business of relaying alarm notifications to the town shall: 
(1)  Send notification of an alarm to the town by an individual. (The reporting of alarms by means of a recorded message is prohibited); 
(2)  Keep his business premises locked and secured at all times; 
(3)  Allow an inspection of his business premises by authorized agents of the director; 
(4)  Notify the town when a permit holder has: 
a.  Initiated, disconnected or transferred service; 
b.  A new person is listed as permit holder; 
(5)  Report alarms only to a telephone number designated by the town; 
(6)  Send alarm notifications to the town in a manner and form determined by the town; 
(7)  Maintain a sufficient staff to ensure that valid alarms are relayed immediately to the town; 
(8)  Inform their customers of permit requirements; and 
(9)  Relay current permit numbers with all alarms. 
(b)  An alarm system company may be assessed a service fee as listed in appendix A of this Code for each incorrect permit number relayed to the town with an alarm notification. Any service fee assessed under the provisions of this section must be paid within 30 days of receipt of notice that it has been assessed by the director. If the assessed fee becomes 90 days delinquent, a ten percent late charge will be added. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.08; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Sec. 30-33. - Service fees for excessive false alarm notifications. 
(a)  The following service fees shall be assessed for excessive false alarm notifications: 
(1)  False burglar alarm notifications . If the permit holder has had three false burglar alarm notifications in the 12-month period immediately preceding any false robbery alarm, he shall be assessed a service fee as listed in appendix A of this Code as set forth therein. 
(2)  False robbery alarm notifications . If the permit holder has had three false robbery alarm notifications in the 12-month period immediately preceding any false robbery alarm notification, he shall be assessed a service fee as listed in appendix A of this Code as set forth therein. 
(b)  A permit holder shall pay assessed fees for any false alarm notification within ten days after notification from the director, by certified mail, that such fees have been assessed. Failure to pay fees may result in revocation of the alarm permit. 
(c)  No service fee shall be assessed against a governmental unit. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.09; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998; Ord. No. 01-07, § 2, 1-18-2007)  
Sec. 30-34. - Protection of financial institutions. 
(a)  A financial institution may install, with the permission of the director, a panel alarm in the police department for the purpose of reporting burglaries and robberies. If such installation is made, all other provisions of this article must be met. The financial institution shall execute a letter of agreement with the town permitting the installation of all necessary equipment on an indicator panel located in the communications section of the police department. The installation must be accomplished at the institution's expense. 
(b)  The letter of agreement shall contain provisions granting a right of inspection to the director, requiring payment of an annual nonrefundable fee as listed in appendix A of this Code for each indicator installed. The rights of a Financial Institution under such a letter of agreement with the town are not transferable. In addition to the matters set forth in the subsection, the letter of agreement shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The director annually may inspect the alarm system at the alarm site and shall require necessary repairs or improvements. If the director finds that the signaling device fails to comply with the requirements of this section, he may terminate the letter of agreement and require the removal of equipment and indicators from the police department. Such removal shall be at the expense of the financial institution. 
(2)  The financial institution shall, at its expense, provide service for the alarm system at the request of the financial institution or the director. In no event shall the town become liable for service charges for repairs and maintenance for any such alarm system. 
(3)  The financial institution may cancel its letter of agreement with the town at any time by giving written notice to the director. Upon giving such notice, the financial institution shall promptly remove its equipment and indicators from the monitor panel in the police department. Such removal shall be at the expense of the financial institution. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.10; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Secs. 30-35—30-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 30-51. - Required. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates or causes to be operated an alarm system or a CATV alarm system without a valid alarm permit issued by the director. An alarm permit is not valid if it has been denied or revoked, has not been renewed or has expired. An alarm permit must be obtained by the person directly responsible for management and control of the alarm site. A separate permit is required for each alarm site. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, governmental units are exempt from all permit requirements. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.02; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998; Ord. No. 62-10, § 3, 10-4-2010)  
Sec. 30-52. - Application. 
(a)  Required information. Each application for a permit required under this article must contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the permit holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the general alarm system or CATV system and payment of the fees assessed under this article. 
(2)  The street address of the property on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated. 
(3)  Classification of the alarm site as either residential, commercial, multifamily or governmental unit. 
(4)  Any business name or title used for the premises on which the alarm system is to be installed or operated. 
(5)  The name of two other persons who have agreed to respond to an alarm if the permit holder is not available. 
(6)  Any other information required by the director which is necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(b)  Grant of approval. Application for a permit under the provisions of this article constitutes a grant of approval for members of the police department to conduct a search for intruders or the fire department to conduct a search for injured or ill persons on the interior of any building on the alarm site found to be unsecured when responding to the alarm site as a result of an alarm notification. 
(c)  False statements; consequences. Any false statement or misrepresentation of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm permit or renewal, or while making a change thereto, shall be sufficient cause of refusal to grant, or revocation of, a permit under this article. 
(d)  Issuance; exceptions. Upon receipt of a completed application form for a permit, the director shall issue a permit unless there is cause to believe the equipment responsible for initiating an alarm will not be maintained or operated in accordance with this article or the applicant will not comply with each provision of this article. Burglary/robbery panel alarms will be limited to financial institutions. 
(e)  Transfer. An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another person. However, the individuals designated to respond to an alarm or relay an alarm may be changed. A permit holder must inform the director of any change that alters information listed on the permit application. No fee will be assessed for such changes. 
(f)  Refusal for particular systems. The director may refuse to permit particular systems which in his discretion have a history of unreliability. 
(g)  Utilization of application contents. For purposes of this article, information contained in the permit application will be used for law enforcement purposes and will become part of the town's utility records. Therefore, all information contained in any permit application shall be deemed confidential, pursuant to V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 552 and House Bill No. 859 (73rd Texas Legislature), and such information contained in the permit application shall not be subject to public disclosure. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.03; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Sec. 30-53. - Application fee. 
A nonrefundable fee for a residential permit or for a commercial permit, as listed in appendix A of this Code, is required for issuance or renewal of an alarm permit and shall be charged for each alarm permit operated under this article. Alarm permits granted under the provisions of this article, unless otherwise specified, shall remain in force for one year from the date of issuance unless suspended or revoked in accordance with the terms of this article. It is the permit holder's responsibility to renew the alarm permit prior to the expiration date. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.04; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998; Ord. No. 62-10, § 3, 10-4-2010)  
Sec. 30-54. - Denial or revocation. 
If the director denies the issuance of a permit, or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action setting forth the reason for such action and advising the applicant or permit holder of the right of an appeal. The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the director to the appeal hearing official by filing a written request for a hearing, setting forth his objections to the action of the director, within ten days after receipt of the notice from the director. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the appeal hearing official shall stay the action of the director in denying the issuance of or revocation of a permit until a final decision on the appeal is made by the appeal hearing official. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.05; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Sec. 30-55. - Penalty for operation without. 
A person commits an offense if he operates any alarm system without having a valid permit in accordance with the provisions of this article and, upon conviction in the municipal court of the town, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 for each offense. Each and every day such violation shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution that, prior to any resultant court date for the violator, the violator obtains an alarm permit from the town. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.06; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Sec. 30-56. - Responsibilities of permit holder. 
(a)  A permit holder must adjust or modify the sensory mechanism of his alarm system to suppress false indications of force so that the alarm system will not be activated by impulses due to: 
(1)  Transient pressure changes in water pipes; 
(2)  Flashes of light; 
(3)  Wind noise caused by the vibrating or rattling of doors or windows; 
(4)  Vehicular noise adjacent to the installation; 
(5)  Other forces unrelated to actual emergencies. 
(b)  A permit holder must maintain the premises containing an alarm system in a manner that ensures proper operation of the alarm system. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to properly maintain the alarm system to prevent false activations. 
(c)  A permit holder must ensure that an alarm system that includes a local alarm, with an audible signaling device mounted on the exterior of a structure, is installed in such a manner whereby the audible signaling device may not be falsely activated and/or continuously reactivated for a period longer than a total of 30 minutes after initial activation. The occurrence of more than three such false activations in any 12-month period will result in revocation of the alarm permit until such time as the director has determined that the audible signaling device has either been rendered inoperable or repaired so as to comply with the provisions of this subsection. If the director suspends a permit under these circumstances, the permit holder may appeal the suspension as provided in section 30-54. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 3.07; Ord. No. 61-97, § 1, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 6-98, § 1, 2-2-1998)  
Secs. 30-57—30-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Regulation of public and private emergency medical services, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 30-91. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Attendant means a person trained and qualified who is responsible for the care of the patients transported by transfer ambulance. An attendant may also serve as driver of a transfer ambulance when trained and qualified to do so. 
Charged-off means to financially relieve the balance of an account based upon a set of conditions provided by the town. 
Driver means a person trained and qualified to drive a transfer ambulance. 
Emergency means any circumstances that calls for immediate action and in which the element of time in transporting the sick, wounded or injured for medical treatment is essential to the health or life of the person. Such circumstances include, but are not limited to, accidents generally, traffic accidents and acts of violence resulting in personal injury and sudden illness. 
Emergency call means any request for emergency medical service that is made by telephone or other means of communication in circumstances which are, or have been represented to be, an emergency and requiring immediate emergency medical service. 
Emergency medical vehicle means any motor vehicle especially designed, constructed, equipped and used for transporting the injured or sick in answer to an emergency call. 
Emergency run means the emergency medical trip to the place where the emergency exists, or from the place of such emergency to a hospital, medical clinic or medical office, or other appropriate destination for the patient. 
Operator means any individual, firm or corporation engaged in the business of transporting the injured, wounded, sick or dead and using the streets of the town for such purpose. 
Street means any street, alley, avenue, boulevard, drive or highway commonly used for the purpose of travel within the corporate limits of the town. 
Transfer ambulance means any motor vehicle constructed, equipped and used for transferring the injured or sick under circumstances which do not constitute an emergency and which have not been represented as an emergency. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 5.01; Ord. No. 49-16 , § 1, 9-6-2016) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-92. - To be provided by fire department. 
(a)  The fire and emergency services departments shall provide emergency medical service. 
(b)  A fee as provided for in the fee schedule found in appendix A of this Code shall be charged per trip for the transportation by emergency medical vehicle of a person to a hospital providing emergency medical aid, in response to a call received by the fire department for emergency medical vehicle service, when an emergency run is made within the town. 
(c)  The person receiving emergency medical service and any person contracting for the service shall be responsible for payment of the fee. In the case of service received by a minor, the parent or guardian of the minor shall be responsible for payment of the fee. 
(d)  The fire and emergency service departments of the town shall transport the injured or sick to the nearest hospital providing emergency medical aid, in accordance with the injury and/or location. 
(e)  Expenses for emergency medical services received by any resident of the town, employee of the town, or member of a political subdivision that has contracted with the town to receive emergency medical service, will be billed to the individual's health insurance company. Any balance remaining will be charged-off by the town. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 5.02; Ord. No. 49-16 , § 2, 9-6-2016)  
Sec. 30-93. - Permitted emergency vehicle operations. 
(a)  It shall not be unlawful for any person operating a state licensed transfer ambulance in the town, who is performing the service of maintaining an emergency medical vehicle at a particular location for a sporting event, to operate such emergency medical vehicle under emergency conditions, using emergency equipment, after notifying the dispatcher and requesting permission to make an emergency run, when a determination is made by the transfer ambulance attendant that an emergency exists requiring the sick or injured person to be transported with all practical speed to a hospital. 
(b)  It shall not be unlawful for any person to operate an emergency medical vehicle to a hospital within the town, if the place of emergency at which the sick or injured was picked up by such emergency medical vehicle is outside the corporate limits of the town, and the emergency medical vehicle making the emergency run is licensed and operated in accordance with V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.001 et seq. 
(Code 1989, ch. 4, § 5.03((2), (3))  
Chapter 32 - ENGINEERING DESIGN CRITERIA AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 70. 
 
Sec. 32-1. - North Central Texas Council of Governments October 2004 Edition of the Public Works Construction Standards - North Central Texas (as amended) and Volumes I and II of the Flower Mound Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual, entitled "Design Criteria (Volume I of II)" and "Construction Standards (Volume II of II)," adopted. 
The North Central Texas Council of Governments (NCTCOG) October 2004 Edition of the Public Works Construction Standards - North Central Texas (as amended) (the "NCTCOG Specifications") and the two-volume Flower Mound, Texas, Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual entitled "Design Criteria (Volume I of II)" and "Construction Standards (Volume II of II)," as they may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted as the engineering standards governing plans and specifications for improvement upon subdivisions of land within the jurisdiction of the town. The two-volume Flower Mound, Texas, Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual adopted hereby may be referred to collectively as "Volumes I and II of the Flower Mound, Texas, Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual" or the "Design Criteria and Construction Standards" and each volume may be referred to in the singular, as appropriate—The "design criteria" or the "construction standards." The NCTCOG Specifications and Design Criteria and Construction Standards are hereby incorporated herein by reference as if fully set out herein. The provisions of Volumes I and II of the Flower Mound, Texas, Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual shall control and prevail in all instances where conflicting with the provisions of the NCTCOG specifications. 
A true and correct copy of the Design Criteria and the Construction Standards adopted by this section are on file in the town secretary's office. Copies of the Design Criteria and the Construction Standards may be acquired, upon payment of the fee(s) established therefor, from the department of infrastructure services. 
(Ord. No. 22-10, § 2, 4-5-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 22-10, § 2, adopted Apr. 5, 2010, repealed the former § 32-1, and enacted a new § 32-1 as set out herein. The former § 32-1 pertained to NCTCOG's Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction and Flower Mound Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual adopted and derived from Code 1989, ch. 3, § 8.01; Ord. No. 15-00, § 2, 2-17-2000; Ord. No. 53-02, § 2, 8-29-2002.  
Sec. 32-2. - Town manager authorized to modify standards. 
The town manager, or his authorized designee, shall be authorized to modify the standards set forth in the NCTCOG specifications during review of the construction of improvements provided any plans and specifications comply with the standards set forth in Volumes I and II of the Flower Mound Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual. 
(Ord. No. 22-10, § 3, 4-5-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 22-10, § 3, adopted Apr. 5, 2010, repealed the former § 32-2, and enacted a new § 32-2 as set out herein. The former § 32-2 pertained to town engineer authorized to modify standards and derived from Code 1989, ch. 3, § 8.02; Ord. No. 15-00, § 2, 2-17-2000; Ord. No. 53-02, § 2, 8-29-2002.  
Sec. 32-3. - Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards Manual—Amendments. 
(a)  The town manager, or his authorized designee, may from time to time make administrative modifications to the construction standards upon the recommendation and advice of the town engineer to address technological advances, changes and improvements to sound engineering practices, and to conform to applicable best management practices. Any and all such administrative modifications to the construction standards shall be enforced as if included in and adopted with the original adoption of this chapter or the most recent amendments to this chapter and shall from time to time be submitted to the town council for ratification and approval. 
The fact that any part or portion of the construction standards have been revised or amended administratively under this provision shall not affect any other portion or provision of the construction standards. Any challenge to an administrative modification shall be raised promptly by the party challenging such modification at which time the administrative modification in question shall be presented to the town council for its review and consideration and, if appropriate, ratification and approval. Any such ratification and approval shall relate back to the date of the administrative modification and shall be as binding as if initially adopted by the town council on such date. 
(b)  All other amendments to the construction standards and all amendments to the design criteria shall be presented to the town's planning and zoning commission for consideration and recommendation to the town council and final action by the town council. A listing of the ordinances that amend the Design Criteria and Construction Standards in whole or in part shall be recorded by ordinance number and date of adoption, or effective date if earlier than the adoption date, in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  The following identified ordinances amend the Design Criteria and Construction Standards in whole or in part: 
From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [15-13], Volume I, entitled "Design Criteria," of the "Engineering Design Criteria And Construction Standards" is hereby amended through the amendment of Part B, "Technical Standards," by amending Section VII, "Town of Flower Mound Access Management Policy and Criteria," by amending the paragraph entitled "Deviation and Dispute Resolution Process," on Page B-VII-7, thereof, by deleting said paragraph in its entirety and replacing it with a new paragraph also entitled "Deviation and Dispute Resolution Process" to read as follows: 
"Deviation and Dispute Resolution Process 
Deviations to these criteria may be approved by the Town Engineer as described in the previous sections. In addition, the Town Engineer is hereby authorized to grant an exception to the access spacing criteria when one property is being developed or redeveloped and the adjacent property is not then being developed or redeveloped and the property not being developed contains an access point that is too close to the access point being proposed on the property being developed or redeveloped provided that the ultimate access points for both properties when they develop or redevelop have already been determined by the Town. The Town Engineer is also hereby authorized to grant an exception to the access spacing criteria in situations where a large physical obstruction, which cannot be reasonably relocated, exists on property being developed or redeveloped and such physical obstruction prevents compliance with the access spacing requirements and the requested deviation therefrom is twenty percent (20%) or less of the standard spacing. 
Disputes will be deferred to and resolved by the Town Council. All access management disputes must be accompanied by a Traffic Impact Analysis paid for by the developer per Town of Flower Mound development procedures." 
From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [51-12], Volume I, entitled "Design Criteria," of the "Engineering Design Criteria And Construction Standards" is hereby amended through the amendment of Part B, "Technical Standards," by amending Section I, "Street Improvements," by amending Subsection A, "Street Classification," by amending Paragraph No. 1, entitled "Definitions," by inserting a definition for the phrase "Urban Minor Arterial with On-Street Parking" as Subparagraph f, and by re-lettering existing Subparagraphs f through j as Subparagraphs g through m, respectively, with the definition of "Urban Minor Arterial with On-Street Parking" to read as follows: 
f.  Urban Minor Arterial with On-Street Parking. 
Urban Minor Arterial with On-Street Parking, means an urban minor arterial with on-street parking. Minor arterial streets are designed to serve traffic originating in or destined for locations within town and are intended to serve traffic traveling through the town. This street type is intended to be used in Mixed Use type environments. It will have two 10' travel lanes provided in each direction with a 16-foot median and 18-foot angled parking on the outside curbs. Curbs would extend to limit parking near intersections to provide better operations and visibility at these locations and reduce the pedestrian crossing distance. This roadway section will typically have large sidewalks to accommodate pedestrians."

From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [21-12], Volume I, entitled "Design Criteria," of the "Engineering Design Criteria And Construction Standards" is hereby amended through the amendment of Part B, "Technical Standards," by amending Section I, "Street Improvements," by amending Subsection A, "Street Classification," by amending Paragraph No. 1, entitled "Definitions," by inserting definitions for the phrases "Urban Minor Arterial with Bike Lane" and "Urban Minor Arterial Undivided" as Paragraphs e and f, respectively, and by re-lettering existing Paragraphs e through j as Paragraphs g through l, respectively, with the definitions being so added to read as follows: 
e.  Urban Minor Arterial with Bike Lane. 
Urban Minor Arterials with Bike Lane serve traffic originating in or destined for locations within Flower Mound and are not intended to serve traffic traveling through the Town. Roadway drainage is provided with curb and gutter. The outside 5' of pavement is to be designated as a 5' marked bike lane for bicycle traffic. 
f.  Urban Minor Arterial Undivided. 
Urban Minor Arterial Undivided roadways are generally located in neighbor-hoods where the ROW is limited and traffic volumes require more than two lanes. Urban Minor Arterial Undivided roadways are intended to serve as the bridge between major arterials and collector streets.

From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [57-11], Volume I, entitled "Design Criteria," of the "Engineering Design Criteria And Construction Standards" is hereby further amended through the amendment of Part B "Technical Standards" by amending Section I "Street Improvements" by amending Subsection G "Pavement Design" by deleting Subparagraph 5 regarding the design of "Gated (Private) Small Scale Green Residential" streets in its entirety and by re-numbering existing Subparagraphs 6, 7, 8, and 9 as subparagraphs 5, 6, 7, and 8, respectively, to read as follows. 
5.  For fire lanes, the minimum pavement and subgrade requirements is 6" of reinforced concrete pavement on 6" of lime or cement stabilized subgrade as recommended by a geotechnical engineer, or 8" of reinforced concrete pavement on 6" of untreated subgrade compacted to 95 percent density. Fire lanes must support a vehicle load of 85,000 pounds. 
6.  Pavement designs should be included for all streets & fire lanes. All pavement subgrade shall be treated so that the treated soil liquid limit does not exceed 35 and the plasticity index does not exceed 15. 
7.  Driveway approaches shall be of the same thickness as the road it abuts to. 
8.  All concrete pavement that is to be installed abutting existing concrete pavement, shall require headers. 
From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [57-11], Volume I, entitled "Design Criteria," of the "Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards" is hereby further amended through the amendment of Part B "Technical Standards" by amending the index of standard pavement details entitled "Streets Construction Standards" immediately following the conclusion of Subsection H "Pavement Construction" to delete and remove the reference to the sheet reflecting the standard paving detail for the "Gated (Private) Small Scale Green Residential" street section. 
From and after the effective date of this Ordinance [57-11], Volume II, entitled "Construction Standards," of the "Engineering Design Criteria and Construction Standards" is hereby amended by amending the index of standard pavement details entitled "Streets Construction Standards" to delete and remove the reference to the sheet reflecting the standard paving detail for the "Gated (Private) Small Scale Green Residential" street section, and by further amending said Volume II, "Construction Standards," by deleting and removing therefrom the street section for a "Gated (Private) Small Scale Green Residential" street that is designated as Detail No. 1, Sheet No. 12, with a revision date of October 2008, in its entirety.
